metadata.title: Evaluation of rheological behavior of 10W40 lubricant containing hybrid nano-material by measuring dynamic viscosity

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Physica E
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/physe
Evaluation of rheological behavior of 10W40 lubricant containing hybrid nano-material by measuring dynamic viscosity
Afshin Ahmadi Nadooshana,⁎, Mohammad Hemmat Esfeb, Masoud Afrandb
a Faculty of Engineering, Shahrekord University, Shahrekord, Iran b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-lubricant Dynamic viscosity Rheological behavior SiO2-MWCNTs powder
A B S T R A C T
In the present paper, the dynamic viscosity of 10W40 lubricant containing hybrid nano-materials has been examined. Hybrid nano-materials were composed of 90% of silica (SiO2) with 20–30 nm mean particle size and 10% of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5– 20 nm. Nano-lubricant samples were prepared by two-step method with solid volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%. Dynamic viscosity of the samples was measured at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and at shear rates of 666.5 s−1 up to 11,997 s−1. Experimental results indicated that the nano-lubricant had non-Newtonian behavior at all temperatures, while 10w40 oil was non-Newtonian only at high temperatures. With the use of the curve fitting technique of experimental data, power law and consistency indexes were obtained; furthermore, these coefficients were assessed by shear stress and viscosity diagram.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A fluid containing solid particles with a smaller size than 100 nm is called nanofluid. Nanofluid is one of the revolutionary developments of fluid and thermal science. These fluids are used in various applications, e.g. heating and refrigeration, automotive, industrial converters, lubrication, nuclear power, electronics, etc. [1,2]. The main advantage of nanofluids is their larger thermal conductivity which is a result of nanoparticles presence and their Brownian motion [3,4]. Identification of thermo-physical characteristics of nanofluids is effectively essential for using them properly. Many studies have been conducted on identifying nanofluids characteristics. These studies have revealed that these characteristics are influenced by various factors, including temperature, nanofluid concentration and diameter of nanoparticles. Studies on thermal conductivity properties indicate that increasing in temperature and concentration of nanofluids or decrease of nanoparticles diameter result in increment of nanofluid thermal conductivity [5–9]. Viscosity is another characteristic that has been studied in many papers. According to these studies, increment of temperature and nanoparticles size or decreasing of nanofluid concentration causes viscosity of nanofluid to decrease [10–16]. Modeling of these properties has been discussed in
some papers. The effect of temperature and concentration on thermal conductivity and viscosity was observed in studies in which neural network was utilized for approximation of nanofluids thermal conductivity and viscosity behavior [17–19]. New equations have been presented in some of these studies for predicting viscosity and thermal conductivity. Table 1 shows some of these equations.
Another characteristic of nanofluids which has not been noticed properly is their rheological behavior. This characteristic is in accordance with any deformation of flow or the shape of a matter which is caused by an external force [22,29–42]. A summary of the studies conducted on this subject is shown in Table 2. The occurred deformation may cause viscosity to either increase or decrease which are called shear thickening and shear thinning respectively. There is a specific type of fluids which is called Bingham fluid. For these fluids viscosity varies linearly with the initial force.
In the present paper our main objective is to discuss the rheological behavior of SiO2-MWCNTs (90%:10%)/10W40 hybrid nano-lubricant and determination of temperature and concentration effects on this nanofluid. This paper is unique since the rheological behavior of this specific nanofluid had not been studied before, so the effects of the studied factors were totally unknown.
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.physe.2017.05.011 Received 11 February 2017; Received in revised form 14 May 2017; Accepted 19 May 2017
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: afshin.ahmadi@gmail.com (A. Ahmadi Nadooshan).
Physica E 92 (2017) 47–54

MARK

sections.heading: 2.1. Material
sections.text:
In this study, SiO2 nanoparticles with the average particle size of 20–30 nm and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5–20 nm were used as nano-additives. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was utilized in order to verify the sizes of the nanoparticles and its results are depicted in Fig. 1.
Physicochemical properties of SiO2 nanoparticles and MWCNTs are shown in Tables 3 and 4 respectively.
The base fluid during this study was 10W40 engine oil and its properties are shown in Table 5.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanofluid preparation
sections.text:
Nanoparticles were weighted using Eq. (1) with volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%. Then 90% of SiO2 nanoparticles and 10% of MWCNTs were dispersed in the base oil

Above equation was used for weighing nanoparticles, where ρ is the density, φ is the nanofluid concentration and w is the measured weight.
Prepared nano-lubricants were mixed two times by using a mechanical blender, two hours for each time. An ultrasonic blender made by (Kimia Nano Danesh Co., Islamic Republic of Iran) with working frequency of 20 kHz and power of 1200 W was utilized for 5– 7 h in order to remove agglomerations of nanoparticles. Fig. 2 illustrates some samples of SiO2, MWCNT, 10W40 oil and the nanolubricant.

sections.heading: 2.3. Viscosity measurement
sections.text:
Viscosity data of SiO2-MWCNTs (90%:10%)/10W40 hybrid nanolubricant were measured for volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1% and temperatures between 5 and 55 °C in the present paper. CAP 2000+ viscometer made by (Brookfield Engineering Laboratories, Inc.) with ± 2.0% accuracy and repeatability of ± 0.5%, was used for measuring viscosity, the measurements were carried out for shear rate ranges of 666.5 s−1 up to 11,997 s−1; the results are shown in Fig. 3. According to the manual of CAP 2000+ Viscometer, ± 1% of measured viscosity should be added to accuracy of the Viscometer. CAP-01 spindle on High Torque has been employed to perform the present experiments, which was calibrated with viscosity
standard fluid (Fluid Part Number: CAP1L) at 25 °C before the measurements.

sections.heading: 3.1. The effects of concentration and temperature on viscosity
sections.text: The effect of temperature and concentration on viscosity of the hybrid nano-lubricant at a constant shear rate is depicted in Fig. 4. It can be observed that increment of temperature resulted in viscosity reduction. This phenomenon was expected because in higher temperatures, the connection between the particles, which prevents the movement of the fluid layers on each other, becomes weaker. In fact, the increase in temperature reduces the van der Waals forces between the particles. It can also be observed that, with increasing the particles volume fraction, the viscosity of nano-lubricant enhances. This observation can be described by the fact that internal shear stress of fluids is related to loading of particles and it increases by increments of particle loading in the base oil. This is caused by increasing in internal friction of the fluid that enables it to resist more against flowing which is synonymous with viscosity enhancement.

sections.heading: 3.2. Rheological behavior
sections.text:
A fluid that acts under power law or Ostwald-de Waele equation is a generalized non-Newtonian fluid in which shear stress is defined as below:
τ mγ= ṅ (2)
μ mγ= ṅ−1 (3)
The equation above defines effective or apparent viscosity and it is a function of shear rate.
In this equation, µ is apparent viscosity, n is power law index, m is consistency factor, τ is shear stress and γ is shear rate. When n value is 1, it exhibits a Newtonian fluid, while values less than 1 are standing for non-Newtonian fluids. Non-Newtonian fluids with n values lower than 1 show shear thinning; in other words they are called Pseudoplastic. Non-Newtonian fluids with n values of higher than 1 present shear thickening behavior.
Diagrams of viscosity and shear stress-shear rate are depicted in Fig. 5. Power law index (n) which is the inclination of the curve is obtained by curve fitting and it is shown in Table 6. In order to obtain nFig. 3. CAP +2000 viscometer.
and m values, Eq. (4) was fitted on shear stress-shear rate curve. Shear stress-shear rate logarithmic diagram for the base oil is shown in Fig. 6.
Ln τ Ln m nLn γ( ) = ( ) + ( )̇ (4)
According to Table 6 and Eq. (2), when temperature lies between 5 and 35 °C, n value of 10W40 oil has been nearly 1, while for temperatures between 45 and 55 °C n values decrease which indicate that the base oil is a Non-Newtonian fluid in high temperatures. Since n values are lower than 1, 10W40 oil shows shear thinning behavior.
Viscosity variations and shear stress of SiO2-MWCNTs/10W40 hybrid nano-lubricant are illustrated in Fig. 7 for 1% volume fraction and various temperatures and shear rates. Natural logarithm (Ln) method was used for calculating of n and m factors of the nanolubricant. Shear stress-shear rate diagram of the sample with 1% volume fraction is depicted in Fig. 8. Curve fitting results of power law index for various temperatures and solid volume fractions are presented in Table 5.
Regarding to Table 7, n values were calculated between 0.7401– 0.9107, which represent non-Newtonian shear thinning behavior of the nano-lubricant. These results can be observed in Fig. 8. Shear rate changes caused non-linear changes of apparent viscosity and shear stress diagrams. This can be described by the Brownian movement of particles dispersed in the base oil, which is different from the Brownian movement of oil's particles. Because of this different movement, fluid and nanoparticles move relative to each other resulting in continuously constructing and breaking off connections between fluid layers and between nanoparticles and fluid.
Power law and consistency indexes against solid volume fraction are depicted in Fig. 9 for different temperatures. Moreover, the exact values of consistency factor for different temperatures and concentrations are presented in Table 8. As shown in Fig. 9, at the temperature of 55 °C, when the nanoparticles loading is increased, power law indexes initially reduce, while they increase afterward representing a fluctuating behavior. This fluctuation is not observable for other temperatures and nano-lubricant does not vary when concentration is increased as the highest variation of the coefficients was 0.06.
According to the consistency diagram, it can be observed that the consistency factor was increased slightly due to the increment of nanolubricant concentration, which is an indication of apparent viscosity increment; this behavior is more considerable at lower temperatures. This can be referred to the random movement of nanoparticles in the base oil. Van der Waals forces between the nanoparticles and the base
oil form clusters of nanoparticles resulting in viscosity increment due to limited mobility of the nanoparticles.
Fig. 10 illustrates power law and consistency indexes at different temperatures for nano-lubricant of 1% volume fraction. It can be observed that decreasing of temperature resulted in increment of consistency index up to 1 which signifies the direct effect of temperature on consistency index and viscosity of the nano-lubricant. The power law index was constant at low temperatures, while at high temperatures, it suddenly decreased by 0.07, indicating that temperature increment intensified the non-Newtonian behavior of the nanolubricant.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study SiO2 nanoparticles of 20–30 nm and multi-walled carbon nanotubes with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5–20 nm were dispersed in 10W40 engine oil with proportion of 90% and 10% respectively, resulting in SiO2-MWCNTs (90%:10%)/ 10W40 hybrid nano-lubricant. Viscosity data of the nano-lubricant were measured for 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1% volume fractions and at temperature ranges of 5–55 °C and shear rates of 666.5 s−1 up to 11,997 s−1.
Studying the extracted data signifies that either of nano-lubricant and 10W40 base oil are non-Newtonian fluids with shear thinning behavior, although 10W40 oil at low temperatures behaves similar to Newtonian fluids. Power law index and consistency factors were obtained with the use of curve fitting technique. The corresponding diagrams signify the fact that increasing of temperature results in power law coefficient and consistency factor reduction. Neural networks were utilized for predicting viscosity data. A neural network was designed so that its outputs were in highest achievable accordance with empirical data, as R-square and mean squared error values were 0.9948 and 0.000194 respectively.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: This work has been financially supported by the research deputy of Shahrekord University. The grant number was SKU-1394-10-MH12.

metadata.abstractText: In the present paper, the dynamic viscosity of 10W40 lubricant containing hybrid nano-materials has been examined. Hybrid nano-materials were composed of 90% of silica (SiO2) with 20–30 nm mean particle size and 10% of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5– 20 nm. Nano-lubricant samples were prepared by two-step method with solid volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%. Dynamic viscosity of the samples was measured at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and at shear rates of 666.5 s up to 11,997 s. Experimental results indicated that the nano-lubricant had non-Newtonian behavior at all temperatures, while 10w40 oil was non-Newtonian only at high temperatures. With the use of the curve fitting technique of experimental data, power law and consistency indexes were obtained; furthermore, these coefficients were assessed by shear stress and viscosity diagram.
